abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Performance Results and
            Accountability Project for Tanzania were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately unsatisfactory, risk to development
            outcome was moderate, Bank performance was moderately
            unsatisfactory, and Borrower performance was moderately
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: a rigorous
            assessment of political economy (PE) risks and the
            formulation of risk mitigation strategy are the key to the
            project success. The complexity of programs and projects has
            to be limited to the existing and likely capacity of
            borrowers and implementers. Reform programs need to be
            aligned with the level of monitoring systems available or
            those which can be reasonably embedded during the project
            period. The low capacity to monitor and coordinate across
            Ministries, Departments and Agencies (MDAs) should have
            indicated that limiting the range and scope of the project
            will be beneficial. Adaptable Program Lending (APLs) also
            tends to bind down the overall structure of the program
            which needs to be related to emerging priorities over time.
            A more efficient way of managing temporary load of work is
            to staff the project with core specialists, recruited for
            the project period, who will work with the designated
            officials and support them. The Public Service Reform
            Program (PSRP) primarily focused on improvements within the
            public service with no direct linkage to the delivery of
            services. Standardization in assessments can ensure that
            across the government performance and accountability is
            measured routinely in a commonly acceptable manner. The
            public service practice needs to define better the links
            between capacities building in specific sectors and impact
            on service delivery. Similarly the link between incentives
            and public service performance needs to be defined more
            credibly. Participation in funds should be selective and
            restricted to areas where there is significant commonality
            of purpose and commonly agreed sector assessments; where
            sector plans are well developed and where the government has
            demonstrated commitment to implementing them. Opportunistic,
            targeted and flexible interventions by the Bank are more
            likely to be successful in public service reform rather than
            large across the board reform programs.
